title-group.article-title: Theoretical and Experimental Studies of Die Casting Techniques for Small Engine Connecting Rods

permissions.copyright-statement: Â© Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc., 1972

abstract.p: A computerized solidification model based on heat transfer theory has been developed for application to die castings to improve their reliability. The model was applied to a small engine connecting rod to investigate the effects of uniform die temperatures, die temperature gradients, insulated coring, melt temperatures, and gate location on solidification patterns. The simulation results indicate that directional solidification cannot be achieved with reasonable die temperature gradients, but can be with a combination of proper gate location and die temperature control. The quality of the connecting rod casting was improved through an instrumentation study of casting variables and by changing gate location and casting procedures as suggested by the solidification model.

ref.mixed-citation: J. G. Henzel and J. Keverian, "The Theory and Applica- tion of a Digital Computer in Predicting Solidification Pat- terns." Jrl. of Metals, Vol. 17, (May 1965), pp. 561-568.

B. F. Caswell and P. Lorentzen, "Some Theoretical As- pects of Heat Transfer in the Die Casting Process." Die Cast- ing Engineer, (March-April 1968), pp. 26-32.
K. E. VanHorn, "Aluminum, Volume I." Metals Park, Ohio: American Society for Metals, 1967.
"Metals Handbook, Volume I." Metals Park, Ohio: American Society for Metals, 1961.
